unit_learning_outcomes.description: Identify and define key concepts and principles of Geographic Information Science, including scale, projections, interactions and interdependence
Utilise standard Geographic Information Science concepts and analytical techniques to develop applications
Organise, analyse and interpret geographic or spatial information using a range of techniques
Perform operations using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Remote Sensing software
Use geographic spatial analysis to effectively communicate through maps and reports

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Class preparation before practical sessions including software installations is required.
Reading of scientific literature and/or viewing lectures online is required during and before practical classes
Additional research is required before practical classes and assessments

assessments.description: Computer-based practical exercise. A report is submitted at the end of the practical.
Covers all material from the lectures and practical classes
Getting started with GIS. This is a computer-based practical exercise.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Fully online/virtual
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances
data.subject_search_title: ENVS2364 - Introduction to Geographic Information Science and Remote Sensing

academic_org.value: Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences

data.description: This unit provides students with a comprehensive introduction to the rapidly evolving field of geospatial technologies, including geographic information systems (GIS), global positioning systems (GPS) and remote sensing. Students will develop broad theoretical skills in geospatial technologies, and practical skills for acquiring and managing spatial data, analysing, visualising and synthesising spatial data, and the principles for applying these skills to real-world problems across a range of disciplines, including environmental science and management, physical and human geography, urban planning, biodiversity conservation, archaeology, health, business and marketing. Adding geospatial technology skills  to your undergraduate or graduate program can help you identify new areas of research and applications thereby strengthening your career prospects.
data.search_title: ENVS2364 - Introduction to Geographic Information Science and Remote Sensing
